caption: Figure 1: BO for a 2D function: (a) True function surface, where the global maximum is marked; (b) Comparison between BO models using GP surrogates (with two AFs) and BKTF with 30 random initial observations, averaged over 20 replications; (c) Specific results of one run, including the final estimated mean surface for f, in which green dots denote the locations of the selected candidates, and the corresponding AF surface.
description: This figure compares the performance of Bayesian optimization (BO) using different surrogate models on a 2D test function.  Panel (a) shows the true function surface with its global maximum highlighted. Panel (b) presents a comparison of the regret (difference between the best objective function value found and the global optimum) over a series of function evaluations for three models: GP with Expected Improvement (EI) acquisition function, GP with Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) acquisition function, and the proposed Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF).  Panel (c) displays a detailed visualization for one of the 20 replications showing the final estimated mean function, the acquired locations (green dots), and the corresponding acquisition function surface for each method.  The figure demonstrates that BKTF shows superior performance in finding the global optimum compared to the GP based models, especially with limited initial data.

caption: Figure 2: Optimization on benchmark test functions, where medians with 25% and 75% quartiles of 10 runs are compared.
description: The figure compares the performance of different Bayesian optimization (BO) methods on seven benchmark test functions.  The x-axis represents the number of function evaluations, and the y-axis shows the regret (the difference between the current best function value and the global optimum). Each subplot corresponds to a different test function with varying dimensions.  The shaded areas represent the 25th and 75th percentiles across 10 independent runs, with the median shown as a solid line. This visualization allows for a comparison of the convergence speed and robustness of various BO algorithms, including the proposed Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) method, against GP-based baselines.

caption: Figure 3: Comparison of hyperparameter tuning for ML tasks: (a) classification; (b) regression.
description: This figure compares the performance of different hyperparameter optimization methods on machine learning tasks.  It shows the results for both classification (using the MNIST dataset) and regression (using the Boston housing dataset). The methods compared include random search (RS), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Bayesian Optimization with Tree-structured Parzen Estimators (BO-TPE), Gaussian Processes with Expected Improvement (GP EI), and the proposed Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) method.  The plots show the accuracy (for classification) and Mean Squared Error (MSE) (for regression) over the number of function evaluations.  This allows for a comparison of the efficiency and effectiveness of the different optimization techniques in finding good hyperparameter settings.

caption: Figure 4: Optimization on the 2D function (Eq. 23): Posterior distributions of model hyperparameters learned by BKTF.
description: This figure shows the posterior distributions of the model hyperparameters learned by the Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) model when applied to the 2D nonstationary and nonseparable function described by equation (23) in the paper.  The left panel displays the posterior distributions of the weight coefficients (λr), while the right panel shows the posterior distributions of the length-scale (l) and noise precision (τ−1) hyperparameters. The different colors represent different ranks (r) of the tensor decomposition. The figure illustrates how BKTF learns the hyperparameters from the data.

caption: Figure 1: BO for a 2D function: (a) True function surface, where the global maximum is marked; (b) Comparison between BO models using GP surrogates (with two AFs) and BKTF with 30 random initial observations, averaged over 20 replications; (c) Specific results of one run, including the final estimated mean surface for f, in which green dots denote the locations of the selected candidates, and the corresponding AF surface.
description: This figure compares Bayesian optimization (BO) performance using different surrogate models on a 2D test function.  Panel (a) displays the true function surface with its global maximum highlighted. Panel (b) presents a comparison of BO performance using Gaussian Processes (GP) with two different acquisition functions (EI and qUCB) and the proposed Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) method, showing the average regret over 20 replications. Panel (c) displays a single run, showing the final estimated function, the locations of the selected candidate points, and the corresponding acquisition function surface.

caption: Figure 6: Optimization on the 2D function (Eq. 23): The last 20 MCMC samples of the latent factors in the two dimensions learned by BKTF.
description: This figure visualizes the last 20 Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) samples of the latent factors for dimensions 1 and 2, learned by the Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) model. Each subplot shows the samples for one latent factor (g1, g2, etc.). The x-axis represents the input variable (x1 or x2), and the y-axis represents the value of the latent factor. The multiple lines in each subplot represent different MCMC samples, illustrating the uncertainty in the estimated latent factors. This visualization helps understand how the BKTF model captures the underlying function's characteristics.

caption: Figure 6: Optimization on the 2D function (Eq. 23): The last 20 MCMC samples of the latent factors in the two dimensions learned by BKTF.
description: This figure shows the last 20 Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) samples of the latent factors learned by the Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) model for a 2D non-stationary and non-separable function.  The latent factors represent the underlying structure of the function in each dimension.  The multiple lines for each latent factor illustrate the uncertainty associated with each factor's estimation. This is a key aspect of the BKTF methodology. The figure demonstrates the flexibility and adaptability of BKTF in characterizing complex functions.

caption: Figure 2: Optimization on benchmark test functions, where medians with 25% and 75% quartiles of 10 runs are compared.
description: The figure compares the performance of different Bayesian optimization methods on seven benchmark test functions across 10 runs. The median regret (the absolute error between the global optimum and the current estimated global optimum) is plotted against the number of function evaluations for each method. The shaded area represents the 25th and 75th percentiles across the runs, illustrating the variability in performance.  The functions are categorized by their dimensionality (2D, 3D, 4D, 6D, 10D). The goal is to show which method achieves a lower regret (better performance) using fewer function evaluations (more efficiency).

caption: Figure 9: Examples of latent factors learned by BKTF on 3D Griewank function.
description: This figure shows examples of latent factors learned by the Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) model for the 3D Griewank function.  The latent factors represent the underlying structure of the function in each dimension and illustrate how BKTF captures the periodic nature of the Griewank function.

caption: Figure 10: Effects of hyperpriors on Branin function: Optimization with different hyperpriors.
description: This figure shows the impact of different hyperprior settings (specifically, the mean of the log-transformed lengthscale hyperparameter μl) on the optimization performance of the BKTF model for the Branin function.  Each line represents a different hyperprior setting.  The y-axis shows the absolute difference between the global optimum and the current estimate, while the x-axis displays the number of function evaluations. The figure demonstrates that the choice of hyperpriors significantly influences the optimization process, highlighting the importance of appropriate hyperprior selection, particularly when the number of observations is limited.

caption: Figure 1: BO for a 2D function: (a) True function surface, where the global maximum is marked; (b) Comparison between BO models using GP surrogates (with two AFs) and BKTF with 30 random initial observations, averaged over 20 replications; (c) Specific results of one run, including the final estimated mean surface for f, in which green dots denote the locations of the selected candidates, and the corresponding AF surface.
description: This figure shows the results of Bayesian Optimization (BO) on a 2D nonstationary, nonseparable and multimodal test function.  Panel (a) displays the true function surface, highlighting the global maximum. Panel (b) compares the performance of BO using Gaussian Processes (GP) with two acquisition functions (EI and qUCB) and the proposed Bayesian Kernelized Tensor Factorization (BKTF) method.  The comparison is based on 30 randomly selected initial observations, averaged across 20 independent runs.  Panel (c) presents detailed results from a single run, showing the estimated mean function surface, the locations of selected candidate points (green dots), and the acquisition function surface.

caption: Figure 12: Effects of rank specification on the test function defined in Introduction (see Appendix C, Eq. 23): Comparison of optimization performance.
description: This figure compares the optimization performance of BKTF with different ranks (2, 4, 6, 8) against two standard GP-based methods (GP αEI and GP αUCB) on a 2D nonstationary nonseparable test function.  The regret, a measure of the difference between the current best solution and the global optimum, is plotted against the number of function evaluations.  It shows how BKTF's performance changes as the rank increases, demonstrating its ability to find the global optimum efficiently with different ranks, while the GP methods struggle.

caption: Figure 13: Effects of rank specification on the test function defined in Introduction (see Appendix C, Eq. 23): Comparison of CRPS.
description: This figure compares the Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS) for different models, including BKTF with various ranks (2, 4, 6, 8) and GP-based models (GP αEI and GP αUCB), across multiple evaluations on a specific 2D test function.  The CRPS metric evaluates the uncertainty quantification (UQ) performance of the models. Lower CRPS values indicate better UQ.
